repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits.

summary.p: The Kantarantāti by Aruṇakirinātar (15th century) is a praise in verse of the god Murukaṉ.

The text (U2: root-text and commentary, interspersed) appears to be complete (2 Kāppu stanzas + 100 stanzas). The bundle appears to be the fragment of a larger bundle, as indicated by the foliation starting at 29 in U2.

We find successively: invocatory stanzas to Gaṇeśa (f29r‒f29v), 2 Kāppu stanzas (f30r‒f33r), the text proper (f34r‒f122v5), that is, 100 stanzas, and a completion statement with benedictions (tuṇai formulae) (f122v5‒f122v7). Each individual stanza (Kāppu stanzas and 100 stanzas that follow) is immediately followed by an individual commentary (urai). The two Kāppu stanzas are numbered 1 to 2 independently and are codicologically separated from the others (f30r‒f33r; f33v is blank).
Paratexts: marginal and in-text benedictions, title-page, marginal title, invocation pages, text completion statement, scribal note (U2, f56v).

collation.desc: 1 folio = Title Page. No foliation. Verso blank.
84 folios = Mūlam & Urai. Tamil foliation 29‒112. 6 to 8 lines per page.
1 folio = guard leaf. No foliation. Double leaf. Blank recto verso. Added along with U1.

supportDesc.condition: Very good state of preservation, in spite of boreholes caused by insects.

additions.desc: BnF shelfmark sticker: INDIEN 375 (front cover, recto).
BnF sticker DON N° (front cover, recto).

binding.p: Pinewood covers apparently fabricated in the BnF.

origin.origDate: Dated to 1840 by Cabaton (1912), on unstated grounds.

acquisition.p: Possibly received, August 1st, 1866, from the Société Asiatique. See BnF, département des Manuscrits, inventaire 7 = Dons: manuscrits et imprimés documentaires, 1848-1895, no. 1192.

provenance.p: Possibly owned by Édouard Ariel (1818-1854). Possibly bequested by Édouard Ariel to Société Asiatique (Rosny 1868, p. 177). See title page folio of the type found in Ariel manuscripts and BnF sticker DON N° .

listBibl.bibl: Cabaton, Antoine (1912). Catalogue sommaire des manuscrits indiens, indo-chinois & malayo-polynésiens. Bibliothèque nationale. Département des manuscrits. Paris: E. Leroux. — See p. 54.

encodingDesc.p: Transliteration conventions ― Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). ― Abbreviations ― c = column, f = folio, lf = library foliation = lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin, U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso.

hari Om The phrase hari O is itself inscribed inside the final m
viṉāyakaṉ pātamē tuṇai
hari Om naṉṟāka Both blessings are inscribed inside a larger Om.
kantarantāti
vāraṇat tāṉai yayaṉaiviṇ ṇōrai malaṟkkarattu ‡
vāraṇat tāṉai makattuveṉ ṟōṉmain taṉaittuvaca ‡
vāraṇat tāṉait tuṇainaya tāṉai vayalaruṇai ‡
vāraṇat tāṉait tiṟaikoṇṭa yāṉaiyai vāḻttuvaṉē ‡‡
Etu vāraṇattāṉai – Ayirāpavatattil intiraṉaiyum – Ayaṉaip – piṟaramāvaiyum –
yātip picakāyp pōṉatu
Ākaiyāl itil oṉṟun tap
pitam illai “It [i.e., the present blank page] occurred [literally “went”] due to memory failure; therefore in this [i.e., the blank page] there is not even a mistake [i.e. a gap in the text].” Scribal note: realising that this page was inadvertently left blank, the scribe added a note to his reader to alert him that there is no discontinuity in the text.
nalkun – taruvaṉ – tiruvaṭiyē – cīrpātamē-y eṉra-v āṟu 100 tiruccittaṟṟampalam
caravaṇa-pava-murukaṉ pātāravintamē tuṇai kantarāntati – muṟṟum –
ciṟai koṇṭa viṉayākar pātamē tuṇai tiruccentūr murukar pātāravintamē tuṇai murukaṉ ṟuṇai
